botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Shrub roses are large shrubs with usually thorny stems bearing large leaves and fragrant, single to double flowers in clusters in summer, and usually also in autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grows best in fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil in a sunny, open position. Mulch in late winter and, to improve flowering, apply a balanced fertiliser in late winter or early spring and again in early summer. See rose cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by semi-ripe cuttings in late summer or hardwood cuttings in autumn
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids, rose leafhopper, glasshouse red spider mite, scale insects, caterpillars, large rose safly and rose leaf-rolling sawfly may be a problem. Deer and rabbits can cause damage
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to rose black spot, rose rust and rose powdery mildew. May also be susceptible to rose dieback, replant disease, canker, honey fungus and a virus
